Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Coupled Reactive Flow at the TAG Hydrothermal Mound
Award.AbstractNarration: From their first discovery in the late 1970's, seafloor hydrothermal vent systems have been an intensive area of study in terms of characterizing the chemistry of their fluids, the biology that thrives around them, and the unique chimney structures that grow from the minerals precipitating from the fluids coming out of the seafloor. Predicting sub-seafloor fluid flow pathways and the dynamics of how these systems operate and evolve in the subsurface, however, still remains elusive due the paucity of holistic mathematical models of the chemical and physical processes that drive these systems. This research develops 2-D and 3-D mathematical models of fluid flow and reactive transport in high temperature mid-ocean ridge seafloor hydrothermal systems. Resulting models take into account mineral dissolution and precipitation and how these change basement permeability, fluid flow, and flow pathways. Goals are to test various hypotheses about what controls the distribution of focused and diffuse flow in high temperature seafloor hydrothermal systems, the extent of mineral precipitation, and the thermal/chemical conditions in the subsurface. The RST2D software package and modifications to it will be used to model the systems. The codes will permit fully-coupled reactive-flow investigations to be carried out which can examine the sensitivity of mid-ocean ridge hydrothermal vent systems to crustal structure, permeability, thermal conductivity, chemical dispersivity, and other geologic variables. Broader impacts of the work include integration of research and education and training graduate students in computational geoscience. Software that will be created during the course of the project builds infrastructure for science and has crossover potential to other fields, such as geothermal energy production and ore deposits. It will be made publicly available over the web. Results of the project will be presented to the public via lectures by participating faculty. The project will also support a PI from a gender under-represented in the sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Submarine mid-oceanic ridges have fascinated scientists and the public for decades ever since hydrothermal vents or springs known as "black smokers"  were first discovered by research/navy submarines such as ALVIN. These vents discharge at temperatures in excess of 660F (~350C) and are thought to be formed by deep seawater circulating through the ancient volcanic seafloor basalt where magma exists at shallow depths (~5000 ft) in the Earth's crust. These fluid circulations generate spectacular precipitation and dissolution of numerous minerals, that provide "fingerprints" of the the chemistry and history of these vents, and form valuable base-metal ore deposits. Many previous NSF studies by many others have studied these vents, either directly by sampling them remotely or indirectly by modeling their theoretical fluid flow patterns using mathematical equations. But until this study, no one has coupled chemical reactions with the hot seawater and rock with the fluid plumbing and crustal heat flow. This was our unique contribution.

Specifically, we sought to address the following questions:

1) What are the likely thermal and chemical environments, including fluxes, present within and at the seafloor at different vent fields?  Such information can provide important clues on likely habitats for microorganisms and macrofauna that require metabolic energy, nutrients, and specific temperature ranges for growth.

2) What boundary conditions and assumed permeability distribution, and changes in permeability from mineral reaction, best reproduce known observations of diffuse/focused fluid locations and ratios, temperature distributions, and chemical differences of fluids?  When observations are best fit, what are the relative percentages of heat flux from focused and diffuse flow at different vent fields? Past estimates have either been extrapolated from small areas to broader areas, or have been estimated from vent plume measurements. Our calculations provided estimates over both scales, and identified factors that control distributions of focused versus diffuse fluid outflow. Our estimates were based on computer simulation of the coupled physics and chemistry.

3) How does mineral precipitation and dissolution affect permeability and porosity and hence fluid flow, fluid chemistry, and temperature distribution within outflow portions of vent systems, and on what time scales?  

This project pioneered new modeling technology for the study of reactive flow in fractured and porous rock, science that transcends several aspects of fluid flow of importance not only to metal ore formation in hydrothermal vents, but also of practical applications in environmental engineering and nano-scale geoscience.  It represents the first fully-coupled reactive flow analysis of a complex geochemical-geological system as a 2-D representation across a mid-oceanic vent. The study also provided a rich learning environment for three young STEM undergraduates in reactive flow modeling from varied backgrounds in geology, chemistry, and engineering. This study sets the stage for more sophisticated modeling in 3-D in future research, and provides a powerful software tool for exploring effects of flow on geologic environments at very high temperature and pressure. We are very grateful for the public support of this research.
